questions.question_text: Which three parameters are used in a compare table formula field to calculate and display a field as percentage value? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BDE
You need column name to find variable, calculation to augment the variable and format to display percentage.
BDE here...

Selected Answer: BDE
This shows that it just use column name calculation and formula

https://trailhead.salesforce.com/pt-BR/content/learn/modules/wave_desktop_exploration/wave_calculating_with_the_compare_table

Selected Answer: BDE
B, D and E are the correct answers. 

To calculate the percentage of a value, you must use the *Column Name* (such as A, B, C), do the *Calculation* (such as A/B), and then select the *Format* (For example Percent(12,34%).
B,D,E is the correct answer

questions.question_text:
A consultant plans to extract an Opportunity object for training and wants to create a story to identify opportunities that are likely to be won.
Which two actions should the consultant take to prepare the training dataset? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Include opportunities that are in all stages for completeness.
choices.D: Include StageName because this field is highly correlated to IsWon (True).

discussion.content:
@Mangoex, I disagree.

Per the question:
"A consultant plans to extract an Opportunity object for training and wants to create a story to identify opportunities that are likely to be won."

identify opportunities that are LIKELY to be won

As such we need to draw a comparison between those that have been won with those that are still in a cycle (not lost).

B and C are the correct answer

Selected Answer: AD
A. Exclude IsClosed (FALSE). → In Einstein Discovery, you want to train the model using historical data where outcomes are known. If an opportunity is still open (IsClosed = FALSE), its outcome is uncertain, which could introduce noise into the model.

D. Include StageName because this field is highly correlated to IsWon (True). → Certain opportunity stages are strong indicators of whether an opportunity will be won or lost. Including StageName helps the model understand key patterns.

Selected Answer: AB
Won Opportunities are Closed by design. The model must be trained on Closed + Won opportunity to identity what make them in that states.
So:
 IsClosed = False shall be excluded (A.)
 We shall maximize IsWon (B.)

Selected Answer: AB
A: you need records with outcome, unclosed records do not have any outcome; B: you need to maximize isWon for model to know, which value are you interested in; C: is the opposite of A, contains lot of records with no meaning for model D: highly correlated values are counterproductive
I think also it's B and C
B and C are better options

Selected Answer: BC
Einstein Discovery only requires an actionable variable and outcome variables - no need to exclude is closed.

Selected Answer: BC
B and C is the correct

Agree with bshreeves. B and C. 
MangoEx logic is flawed. You can’t train a model to maximise an expected outcome by ONLY supplying it with data where the outcome is already maximised. You need a comprehensive dataset that cuts across multiple scenarios so that the model can learn what drives the intended outcome.

Selected Answer: AB
A and B are the correct answers.

We are only interested in opportunities that have already reached the outcome. For Opportunities, it typically means when the Opportunity is closed (IsClosed= true), so we do not need isClosed = false. You may also consider filtering for a specific segment of your data as insights that drive faster sales for your enterprise customers may be completely different from your small business customers. 

We are not using StageName, because this field designates the sales process stage. Since we are training when IsWon=true, the model will only know the stage “Closed Won”. When it sees stages like “Qualification”, for example, the model won’t know what to do with that value and consider it out of bounds for the model.

https://www.salesforceblogger.com/2020/03/11/preparing-your-data-for-einstein-discovery/
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

choices.B: Start over again with new dataflows that exclude unused fields with a filter to extract relevant data.
choices.C: Update the existing data sync (replication) process by removing unused fields with a filter to extract relevant data.
choices.A: Modify dataflows to exclude unused fields and include a filter to extract relevant data.
choices.D: Scale down the number of datasets to help improve data sync (replication) performance.

discussion.content: C is the best option here.

C. 
A and B don’t even talk about data sync and D is just silly.

C
Update the existing data sync (replication) process by removing unused fields with a filter to extract relevant data.

questions.question_text:
A Tableau CRM consultant is notified of a performance issue with data sync (replication). The consultant researches the issue and determines that unnecessary data is being synced.
Which solution should the consultant implement to help improve data sync (replication) performance?

discussion.content: C,D ist the correct answer

Selected Answer: AD
A. Records from a Salesforce object → Recipes can pull data directly from Salesforce objects as a source.

D. Existing datasets → Recipes can use existing datasets within CRM Analytics to transform and create new datasets.

comments.content:
Why not c
C. Connected data (Synced) → Synced data is stored in the connected data layer, but recipes use datasets or Salesforce objects, not directly synced data. However, once synced data is used to create a dataset, it can be used in a recipe.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
It is possible to sync more, but definitely Connected data and Existing datasets are available. Records from a Salesforce object is not a source type.

I think A and D are correct
When you are in the recipe you can click the top left button 'Add Input Data', then you have 3 options:
1. CRM Analytics Datasets (Which you can call it existing datasets)
2. External Connected Objects
3. Salesforce Objects

When you look into Saleforce Objects you can see a list of already Synched and the rest of Saleforce Objects to create a connection.
C and D are best options. A could be... but with this wording I'd exclude it.... B is nonsense.

Selected Answer: CD
ofc CD are the correct answers. 
A: wording is wrong. You can use -among others - Salesforce Objected to which a connection is established, which falls under C: Connected data(synced).
B: doesn't make any sense.

Selected Answer: CD
C,D is correct

comments.content: Or maybe it is not true beacuse it is *records* from salesforce object...

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
When you are in the recipe you can click the top left button 'Add Input Data', then you have 3 options:
1. CRM Analytics Datasets (Which you can call it existing datasets)
2. External Connected Objects
3. Salesforce Objects
theirfore I am voting for A and D, Salesforce objects and existing datasets

Selected Answer: CD
C and D are the correct answers.

After clicking the Add Data button, you select either the Datasets or Connected Data tab (it means the objects that were already synced), and click the dataset or object that you want to add.
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

questions.question_text:
A Tableau CRM consultant decides to use a recipe to create a new dataset.
Which two source types can be used for the recipe? (Choose two.)

After loading data to Einstein Discovery and creating a story, the client asks the Einstein consultant to explain the Unexplained Bar in the "Why does this do better/ worse" chart.
Which explanation is correct?

choices.D: It displays the difference between the analyzed data and the data not reviewed.
choices.A: It shows the difference between the predicted outcome and the observed outcome.
choices.B: It only appears for outcomes that do not have an explanation.
choices.C: It should always be 0 or the model should not be used.

discussion.content: A is the correct answer

Selected Answer: A
A is the correct answer. 

Unexplained bar lays out the comparison between the *predictions made* for all observations in the requested subset, and their overall average, compared with the *observed average*.

https://www.biztory.com/blog/understanding-einstein-discovery-stories-in-einstein-analytics

Correct! 
Based on the following links:
- https://www.biztory.com/blog/understanding-einstein-discovery-stories-in-einstein-analytics#:~:text=Unexplained-,Unexplained%20bar,-lays%20out%20the

- https://help.salesforce.com/s/articleView?id=sf.bi_edd_insight_why_average.htm&type=5#:~:text=6-,Unexplained,-Represents%20the%20unexplained
Question was on exam 21 August 2022.

exam.name: Certified Tableau CRM and Einstein Discovery Consultant
